title.text: Citius at SemEval-2017 Task 2: Cross-Lingual Similarity from Comparable Corpora and Dependency-Based Contexts

abstractContent.text: This article describes the distributional strategy submitted by the Citius team to the SemEval 2017 Task 2.
Even though the team participated in two sub-tasks, namely monolingual and cross-lingual word similarity, the article is mainly focused on the cross-lingual sub-task.
Our method uses comparable corpora and syntactic dependencies to extract count-based and transparent bilingual dis-tributional contexts.
The evaluation of the results show that our method is competitive with other cross-lingual strategies, even those using aligned and parallel texts.

introductionContent.text: A comparable corpus consists of documents in two or more languages or varieties which are not translation of each other and deal with similar topics.
Comparable corpora are by definition multilingual and cross-lingual text collections.
The use of comparable corpora for word similarity is a well-known task).
The main advantage of comparable corpora is that the Web can be used as a huge resource of multilingual texts.
In contrast, their main drawback is the low performance of the extraction systems based on them.
According to), word similarity extraction from comparable corpora is a too difficult and ambitious objective, and much more complex than extraction from parallel and aligned corpora.

entities.text: word similarity extraction from comparable corpora

introductionContent.text: However, the reasonable results our comparablecorpus method achieved in the cross-lingual subtask of show that the gap between parallel and comparable corpora for word similarity is shortening.
